The graph shows the horizontal position <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the block as a function of time <math alttext="t"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as the block oscillates on the surface. (b) Calculate the maximum linear speed of the block.
(c) Calculate the maximum force exerted on the block.
(d) Calculate the spring constant of the spring.

The block is moving to the right when it breaks away from the spring moving with its maximum linear speed. The block reaches an area with a rough surface that has a coefficient of kinetic friction of <math alttext="0 point 2 0"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (e) Calculate the distance the block moves on the rough surface as it comes to rest.

The block is then replaced with a cylinder of radius <math alttext="0 point 2 5 meters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.25</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and mass <math alttext="2 point 0 kilograms"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is attached to the spring along an axis through its center. The cylinder is placed on a new surface, which allows it to roll while in oscillation. The cylinder is pulled back until the spring is stretched the same distance as in the previous experiment, and the cylinder is released from rest. (f) Will the maximum linear velocity of the cylinder be greater than, less than, or equal to the maximum linear velocity of the block? ____ Greater than ____ Less than ____ Equal to Justify your answer.
